RFC-21 Postnuke International
Postnuke RFC-21 Postnuke International Category: Informational Version: 0.5 June 2002 RFC-21 Postnuke International Table of Contents 1. Introduction 2. List of requirements for Postnuke International 3. Solution proposals 5. Relationships to other Systems 6. Code that will need to be rewritten 7. Basic documents for this RFC 8. Tools that need to be created from scratch 9. Retractions 10. Acknowledgements 11. Open Issues 12. Changelog Informational RFC-21 Postnuke International June 2002 1. Introduction The goal of Postnuke International is to leverage the international nature of the PostNuke project to further various aspects of the project, including, but not limited to: Support PR User Feedback Documentation Having Fun 2. List of requirements for Postnuke International Provide Support in many languages Share experiences Have a common backend to share content Create an escalation procedure for unresolved problems Increase traffic to partner sites Resolve scalability issues with the main support site Foster local communities Attract talent to PostNuke Spread the word about PostNuke Raise quality accross all sites Some of the problems we want to address with Postnuke International are: Language barriers: not everyone speaks / understands english Support information is hard to find It is hard to discover language / country specific PostNuke sites Problem reports tend not to flow back to the developers Translated documenation is sometimes hard to find International Support without support News of Postnuke only in Postnuke site and not translated and put i all sites Developpers, maybe other country have a good developper but they not speak/understand english Postnuke project don't have Official International Support site Comunication with Official Postnuke and other support site News: Postnuke.com -> International sites (by hand, webmasters checking postnuke.com, modules.*, blocks.* themes.*, mailing lists..., broswing forums..., other international sites...) Documentation: Flow broken. There are part of documentation on docs.postnuke.com, part on international sites. Without consistency of content and/or look. Feedback: Needs to be more dinamic. Bug report on a non english site by a non english speaker right now means webmaster to understand completely bug to submit it. Some bug fixing is done on the fly on country/language specific sites FAQ: Make a real FAQs based on experience of language-based support teams. It'll help on the way of developing end user and administrator documentation 3. Solution proposals Here are some partial solution ideas. Those need to be fleshed out a lot more. Syndication of news, forums (Mailbag?) to exchange news, forward interesting threads for archival or as input for pnFeedback (bug tracker / feature request). close the loop with the documentation / FAQ team Heavy, deep interlinking (not just in the web links section) for instance on pn.it forum: go to the same forum on pn.com etc Adopt a similar structure for the support forums so that they can be mapped from language to language, from main site to 3rd party sites etc Make documentation readily available (people have trouble finding our docs, including translations Make sure people read the FAQ before they ask problems, and related, create escalation steps to verify issues so that they can be tackled by developers. Work with documentation people to continually identify top issues, and make FAQ / docs out of them Create language-specific IRC channels on the PostNuke IRC Network 5. Relationship of Postnuke International to other areas pnCommunity: Postnuke International should plug into pnCommunity for User Feedback and other areas 6. Code that will need to be rewritten News submission should support multiple destinations 7. Tools that need to be created from scratch Site synchronization tools Update notification tools 9. Retractions We list features that were considered but rejected for Postnuke International below. PHP Nuke sites: It was felt that PHP Nuke sites do not fit into Postnuke International unless they have substantial Postnuke resources. 10. Acknowledgements Timax Zoom Xaplo Almer (Russia) ?NukeZine 11. Open Issues Contested Sites In many cases there are two or more Postnuke sites per country. Agreeing on one official site per country is highly unlikely. The goal should be to have as many sites as part of Postnuke International as possible while still maintaining the quality of the network. Examples of contested sites include: postnuke.de versus post-nuke.com various french sites - Do anybody have links of french sites besides Boomtchak? various scandinavian sites - This issue was solved imho? pure PostNuke sites vs sites with mixed content Uniformity vs Creative Freedom The wish to achieve some level of uniformity among sites of Postnuke International might clash with the wish to do things differently. 12.
